description: From Middle English fracture, from Old French fracture, from Latin fractūra (“a breach, fracture, cleft”), from frangere (“to break”), past participle fractus, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰreg-, from whence also English break. See fraction. Doublet of fraktur.

entries.meaning: An instance of breaking, a place where something has broken.
(medicine) A break in bone or cartilage.
(geology) A fault or crack in a rock.

verbs.description: fracture (third-person singular simple present fractures, present participle fracturing, simple past and past participle fractured)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To break, or cause something to break.
(transitive, slang) To amuse (a person) greatly; to split someone's sides.
